Department of Chemistry Universitas Indonesia Depok Depok 16424 Indonesia 2,5-Furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) has attracted considerable interest as a sustainable monomer for producing biodegradable polymers such as poly(ethylene furanoate) (PEF), offering a sustainable alternative to petrochemical-derived materials. FDCA may be produced by oxidizing 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), which itself is commonly obtained from the dehydration of fructose or related hexose isomers. This study utilized a nickel oxide-modified ZSM-5 catalyst to facilitate the conversion process. Comprehensive physicochemical analyses were conducted on both ZSM-5 and its NiO-modified counterpart using methods such as X-ray diffraction, infrared spectroscopy, X-ray fluorescence, scanning electron microscopy, nitrogen physisorption, and ammonia temperature-programmed desorption. Catalytic tests followed a two-stage strategy: glucose dehydration to HMF, and subsequent HMF oxidation to FDCA, with reaction parameters optimized by Box–Behnken design. The highest HMF yield (30.94 %) was obtained at 160 °C for 2.36 h using 0.4 mL of gamma-valerolactone (GVL) and 3.6 mL of water. The optimal FDCA yield from HMF (36.05 %) was achieved at 90 °C for 12 h in pure GVL (4 mL). To simplify the process, a one-pot system combining both steps was also explored, resulting in a final FDCA yield of 4.22 % under optimized conditions (GVL:water ratio 0.4:3.6) with NiO/ZSM-5, demonstrating the catalyst's potential in sustainable FDCA production. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords FDCA Glucose NiO/ZSM-5 Gamma valerolactone (GVL) Box–Behnken design Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Bioplastics and biodegradable polyesters based on FDCA have garnered increasing global attention as potential solutions to the environmental challenges posed by petroleum-based plastics. FDCA is a biomass-derived compound that serves as a key monomer in the synthesis of polyesters with unique properties, such as high thermal stability and low gas permeability. One of the primary applications of FDCA is in the production of poly(ethylene furanoate) (PEF), which is considered a promising alternative to PET due to its comparable physical and mechanical properties, along with superior biodegradability and a reduced environmental footprint [1]. The widely adopted route for producing FDCA is through HMF oxidation. While HMF is typically derived from fructose dehydration, it can also be sourced from other hexoses like glucose and D-fructofuranose. Many high-value chemicals have already been synthesized starting from HMF. For example, 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF), which results from HMF reduction, is utilized in polymer synthesis and as a precursor for therapeutic compounds and other value-added chemicals [2]. Among these derivatives, FDCA is highlighted as one of the most promising platform chemicals, recognized by the U.S. Department of Energy [3], due to its molecular resemblance to terephthalic acid and its potential as a renewable monomer for biodegradable plastics [4]. The oxidation of HMF to FDCA generally involves sequential formation of partially oxidized intermediates such as 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), 5-formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA), and 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA) [5,6]. These intermediates are of interest for further development of bio-based products including biofuels, resins, and surfactants. Over the last decade, extensive research has focused on developing various catalytic systems to convert HMF or its derivatives into FDCA. Selective partial oxidation of HMF under specific catalysts and reaction conditions can yield different intermediates like HMFCA, FFCA, or DFF. Recent studies have also explored glucose conversion into HMF using various catalysts, including lignin-derived carbon-supported tin oxides (SnOx/LC) [7], bimetallic hafnium–aluminium oxides (Al-HfOx) [8]. Various catalysts have been explored for the synthesis of FDCA, typically via the oxidation of HMF [9,10]. For instance, the Sn-Al-Beta zeolite has demonstrated selective activity for converting glucose to HMF, achieving a maximum yield of 31 % (78 % conversion) at 160 °C for 12 h, with performance largely influenced by the Brønsted to Lewis acid site ratio and the use of a water–DMSO solvent mixture [11]. A Pt/C catalyst has also been tested, though it resulted in lower yields, around 79 % over 6 hours under 6.9 bar O₂ pressure [12]. Meanwhile, MIL-101(Cr)-NH₂, a metal-organic framework catalyst, converted glucose into HMF with a maximum yield of 55 % at 180 °C for 3 h in a DMSO–water system, where Box-Behnken and ANOVA analyses identified temperature and time as the most influential variables [13]. Among these alternatives, ZSM-5 was selected in this study due to its excellent thermal and hydrothermal stability, adjustable acidity through Si/Al framework tuning, and well-defined MFI structure, which can be engineered into a hierarchical micro–mesoporous network. Prior study from our research group has successfully converted HMF to FDCA via one-pot synthesis method utilizing ZSM-5 modified with CuO and NiO, which demonstrated efficient conversion of HMF to FDCA, achieving an FDCA yield of 88.9 %. However, the conversion of glucose to HMF remains a critical challenge, often exhibiting suboptimal efficiency that hinders the overall success of the reaction sequence [14]. Therefore, this study focuses on enhancing the conversion of glucose to HMF by modifying ZSM-5-based catalysts with NiO, and by applying a Box–Behnken experimental design within the Response Surface Methodology (RSM) framework to systematically determine optimal reaction parameters. The hierarchical porous nature of ZSM-5 improves reactant diffusion toward active catalytic sites, leading to better yields and selectivity. Although metal oxide-modified ZSM-5 catalysts have demonstrated encouraging activity, optimizing reaction conditions remains crucial. Using Box–Behnken Design within RSM allows for accurate identification of optimal conditions with fewer experimental runs [15]. Additionally, employing GVL as a reaction solvent in the one-pot system is anticipated to enhance FDCA yield, especially during the glucose dehydration step to HMF. GVL itself is known as a polar aprotic solvent and can function as a solvent or co-solvent to help produce higher-value products from lignin, carbohydrates, sugars, and related compounds [16,17]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98 %), sodium aluminate (NaAlO2), tetra- propylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 40 %), and poly(diallyldimethylammonium) chloride (PDDA-Cl, 20 %) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, analytical grade, Merck), 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF, analytical grade, Merck), 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA, 97 %, analytical grade, Merck), γ-valerolactone (GVL, 99 %), 5-formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA, analytical grade, Merck), 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF, analytical grade, Merck), 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA, ≥95 %, analytical grade, Merck) potassium carbonate (K2CO3, ≥99 %, analytical grade, Merck), glacial acetic acid (CH3COOH, analytical grade, Merck), hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂, 30 %, analytical grade, Merck), methanol (CH3OH, LC-grade, Merck), sulfuric acid (H2SO4 analytical grade, Merck). 2.2 Synthesis of catalyst 2.2.1 Synthesis of ZSM-5 zeolites Hierarchical ZSM-5 zeolites containing inter-crystalline mesopores were synthesized based on the mesopore-free crystallization method reported by Herlina et al. [14]. The molar composition used was 1 Al2O3: 64.35 SiO2: 10.08 (TPA)2O: 3571.66 H2O. NaAlO₂ served as the alumina source, while TEOS acted as the silica precursor. TPAOH was employed as a structure-directing agent for forming the MFI-type framework. Additionally, PDDA-Cl was added as a mesoporogen to introduce hierarchical porosity. All components were continuously stirred over a period of 48 hours at 25 °C, then crystallized in an autoclave for 144 hours at 170 °C. After crystallization, the product was filtered, washed to pH 7, and dried at 60 °C. Finally, calcination was performed at 550 °C under static air to remove organic templates and form the final ZSM-5 structure [18]. 2.2.2 Modification NiO/ZSM-5 Preparation of the NiO/ZSM-5 catalyst employed the incipient wetness impregnation approach [19]. Nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate was dissolved in distilled water to make a 10 % (w/w) solution, which was mixed thoroughly with 1 g of ZSM-5 for 48 hours until a homogeneous paste was formed at 25 °C. The sample was then dried at 60 °C for 12 hours and calcined at 550 °C. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The crystalline phase of the catalyst was evaluated using X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis, conducted on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54 Å). Functional groups were characterized by Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy (Alpha-Bruker), performed with the potassium bromide pellet technique and a spectral resolution of 4 cm⁻¹. Elemental composition was determined using X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analysis, employing a PANalytical Epsilon 3XL spectrometer operated at 50 kV with a silver (Ag) anode. Textural properties, including surface area and pore size distribution, were assessed by N₂ physisorption. Morphological analysis was conducted using Scanning Electron Microscopy equipped with Energy Dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (Prisma E SEM, Thermofisher Scientific) to observe particle shape, surface features, and elemental distribution. In addition, crystallite size distribution was evaluated by analysing SEM images using ImageJ® software. Prior to analysis, the samples were degassed at 300 °C under vacuum for 1 h. NH₃-TPD was also performed to determine acidity profiles using a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument. 2.4 Optimization of glucose conversion to FDCA For the optimization of the glucose-to-FDCA conversion reaction, a statistical Box-Behnken design was employed using three variables and fifteen experimental runs, conducted with Minitab Statistical Software version 22. The variables included solvent volume (X1), reaction temperature (X2), and reaction time (X3). The interval values for each variable were determined based on the expected optimal conditions of the reaction. The reaction parameters were obtained through the Box–Behnken method, as presented in Table S1. 2.5 Catalyst test In this catalytic test, 0.25 g of substrate, 10 % of catalyst, and 0.75 g of K₂CO₃ were combined with 5 mL of a 2 % H₂O₂ solution and an appropriate amount of GVL/water mixture, then transferred into a 20 mL sealed vial. The vial was placed in an oil bath and stirred continuously to ensure homogeneous mixing. Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was filtered to separate the catalyst, and the liquid phase containing HMF and its derivatives was analysed using HPLC PG LC210 equipped with a C18 column and UV detection at 25 °C. The analysis employed a mobile phase consisting of 5 mM aqueous H₂SO₄ and methanol in a 9:1 ratio, flowing at 1 mL/min [14]. The product yield (%) and turnover frequency (TOF) were subsequently calculated using the following equation: (2) Product yield ( % ) = [ Product ] outlet × V m inlet × 100 % (3) TOF ( h − 1 ) = Amount of product formed ( mol ) Number of catalytic acid sites ( mol ) × reaction time ( h ) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization XRD analysis was performed to elucidate the crystalline structure of the catalyst samples. The diffraction peaks enable the distinction between crystalline and amorphous phases, and verification of crystal phase, degree of crystallinity, crystallite size, as well as structural changes after metal-oxide modification [20]. Fig. 1 (a) shows the diffractograms of pristine ZSM-5 and NiO-modified ZSM-5. The XRD pattern of the synthesized ZSM-5 matches that of the reference ZSM-5, confirming successful synthesis. Characteristic reflections at 2θ = 7.97°, 8.82°, 8.92°, 23.08°, and 23.32° correspond to the (101), (200), (020), (332), and (051) planes of the ZSM-5 MFI framework (ICDD 00-044-0003). Their sharpness indicates high crystallinity [21]. The crystallite size was estimated using the Debye–Scherrer equation, yielding an NiO crystallite size of 6.2 nm. Comparison of the XRD patterns shows that all characteristic MFI peaks remain after impregnation, indicating the zeolite framework is preserved. New diffraction peaks at 37.2°, 43.3°, and 62.9°, indexed to the (111), (020), and (022) planes of cubic NiO (COD 96-101-0096), appear only in NiO/ZSM-5, confirming successful NiO deposition. To quantify structural changes, the relative crystallinity after NiO modification was determined from the total integrated peak area of the ZSM-5 signature regions (2θ = 7–9° and 21–25). Following ASTM D5758-01 [22,23], the synthesized ZSM-5 exhibits a crystallinity of 74 %, which rises to 100 % after NiO impregnation, evidence that NiO not only preserves but can enhance lattice order during high-temperature calcination [24]. The emergence of NiO peaks together with the higher crystallinity confirms successful deposition of crystalline NiO on the external surface of ZSM-5, yielding a composite that combines the catalytic attributes of both ZSM-5 and NiO. Structural stability helps maintain open zeolite channels during the reaction, facilitating the diffusion of glucose and HMF molecules within the pores. Complementary to XRD, FTIR provided insight into functional groups and framework integrity by identifying characteristic vibrations of the SiOSi and AlOSi bonds within the aluminosilicate lattice, as well as hydroxyl groups responsible for Brønsted acidity [25]. Fig. 1(b) presents the FTIR spectra, the distinct absorption observed at 1099 cm⁻¹ is attributed to the asymmetric stretching of SiOSi linkages, while the symmetric mode appears at 806 cm-1 [26]. Additionally, the peak at 547 cm⁻¹ is assigned to “five-membered ring” vibrations within the pentasil (MFI) framework, reflecting the long-range order of ZSM-5 [27]. Prior to calcination, the as synthesised zeolite exhibits –CH2- sp2 stretching bands at 2 800–2 900 cm-1, residual organics from the TEOS precursor and a broad OH band of high intensity. Calcining at 550 °C removes these organics: the CH bands disappear and the OH intensity drops, leaving only weak contributions attributable to adsorbed water. For NiO/ZSM-5, additional features appear in the 450–600 cm-1 region, where Ni–O lattice vibrations are normally observed [28–30]. Although the Ni–O band near 553–554 cm-1 partially overlaps the T–O–T vibration of the zeolite, subtle peak shifts confirm successful incorporation of NiO into (or onto) the ZSM-5 framework. This assignment is consistent with Bashir et al., who report an NiO signature at 553 cm-1 [31]. The presence of active hydroxyl groups indicates Brønsted and Lewis acid sites involved in the dehydration and oxidation pathways. Taken together with the XRD data, the FTIR results verify that the crystalline MFI framework is preserved after NiO impregnation while new NiO related bands attest to the formation of the desired composite catalyst. In addition, XRF analysis was performed to validate the elemental composition and verify the incorporation of Ni within the NiO/ZSM-5 catalyst. As a non-destructive method, XRF is commonly applied to quantify and identify elemental constituents in materials. This method relies on the interaction of X-ray radiation with atoms in the sample [32]. In the context of zeolites, XRF is particularly useful for quantifying the Si/Al ratio, which directly influences the material’s acidity and thermal stability, as well as for determining the presence of metals such as Ni, Cu or Ag incorporated into the zeolite framework. Due to its high sensitivity and non-invasive nature, XRF is well suited for detecting both major elements and trace impurities without altering the sample [33]. ZSM-5 is a type of zeolite composed of interconnected TO₄ tetrahedra (where T typically represents Si or Al), forming a three-dimensional framework. These tetrahedral layers can undergo slight distortions and shifts, giving ZSM-5 a flexible structure capable of adapting its symmetry and crystal form. According to the XRF results in Table 1 , the primary components of the synthesized catalyst samples are silicon and aluminium. These values indicate that both materials retain an orthorhombic crystal structure, as the Si/Al ratio remains below 85, a threshold generally associated with this structural form. The orthorhombic structure reflects a relatively symmetrical and thermally stable crystal lattice post-calcination [34]. The analysis indicates that introducing NiO through impregnation did not lead to either dealumination or desilication of the ZSM-5 framework [35,36]. The XRF data further supports the findings from XRD and FTIR analyses. The presence of Ni detected by XRF aligns with the distinct NiO diffraction peaks observed in the XRD pattern of NiO/ZSM-5, as well as the characteristic Ni–O vibrational band identified in the FTIR spectrum. Taken together, these results confirm the successful incorporation of NiO into the zeolite structure, along with a measurable increase in the Si/Al ratio after modification, underscoring the complementary role of XRF in validating both structural and compositional changes in the catalyst. N2 adsorption tests were carried out to assess the textural characteristics of ZSM-5 and NiO/ZSM-5. The adsorption isotherms for both catalysts, as shown in as Fig. 2 a, display a typical type IV profile with an H4-type hysteresis loop at high relative pressures, indicative of the presence of slit-like mesopores within the synthesized ZSM-5 framework [37]. This observation confirms the effective incorporation of mesopores into the microporous framework of ZSM-5, which can be attributed to the use of PDDA-Cl as a mesopore-directing agent during synthesis. Therefore, it can be concluded that the final ZSM-5 material exhibits a hierarchical or micro–mesoporous structure [38]. The incorporation of NiO into the hierarchical ZSM-5 did not alter the overall shape of the N₂ adsorption–desorption isotherms, indicating structural integrity. However, a decrease in the amount of adsorbed nitrogen was observed during the N₂-physisorption process, suggesting a reduction in the surface area of the material after ZSM-5 was modified with NiO. The specific surface areas (SBET) and overall pore volumes (Vtotal) obtained from BET and t-plot analyses for the synthesized catalysts are shown in Table 1. ZSM-5 displays a BET surface area of 371 m²g-1 with a micropore area (Smicro) of 230 m² g-1 and an external surface area (Sext) of 140 m² g-1. After NiO modification, the BET surface area of NiO/ZSM-5 decreases to 332 m² g-1, with Smicro falling to 193 m² g-1 and Sext remaining essentially unchanged at 139 m² g-1. Pore-size analysis, derived from the BJH distributions in Fig. 2b, shows that ZSM-5 possesses pores of ∼2.51 nm and ∼25.25 nm, whereas NiO/ZSM-5 exhibits slightly enlarged pores of ∼2.73 nm and ∼25.25 nm. These N2-physisorption results reveal a pronounced alteration in textural properties following NiO deposition. The overall BET area drops from 371 m² g-1 to 332 m² g-1, driven chiefly by the reduction of micropore area (230 → 193 m² g-1), while the external surface remains essentially constant. At the same time, the total pore volume (Vtotal) increased from 0.16 to 0.19 cm3g-1, along with a slight rise in mesopore volume (Vext, from 0.11 to 0.09 cm3g-1) and a reduction in micropore volume (Vmicro, from 0.05 to 0.03 cm³g-1). The observed increase in average pore diameter, from 2.52 to 2.73 nm, suggests the formation of larger void spaces, reflecting enhanced mesoporosity. These changes suggest that NiO particles deposit on the zeolite surface and partially block micropores, while their aggregation creates additional mesoporous cavities. This interpretation aligns with Debye–Scherrer results, which reveal that the mean NiO crystallite size (∼6.2 nm) surpasses the native ∼2.5 nm mesopores of ZSM-5, supporting the notion that NiO resides mainly on external surfaces or within the wider pores of the hierarchical framework. Furthermore, the presence of mesopores enhances the diffusion of large molecules such as glucose, HMF, and FDCA, which is crucial for maintaining reaction efficiency throughout the process. To further investigate the morphology of the materials, SEM was conducted. As shown in Fig. 3 (a) at various magnifications, ZSM‑5 displays stacked, elongated hexagonal plates, morphology consistent with previous reports by Ba Mohammed et al., H. Chen et al., and Meng et al. [39–41]. SEM inspection reveals no shape distortion or structural damage after NiO impregnation; the well‑defined MFI crystals remain intact, indicating that metal loading does not compromise the zeolite framework. The main morphological difference is the presence of fine particles on the surface of NiO/ZSM-5 crystals, attributed to the deposition of NiO, as seen in Fig. 3(b). A uniform distribution of active metals facilitates better access to active sites, supporting more efficient reactions and enhancing the overall catalytic performance. The appearance of fine grains on the crystal surfaces, attributable to deposited NiO particles, is further confirmed by the elemental mapping in Fig. 3(c) shows that the elemental mapping results show that Na, Si, Al, O, and Ni are evenly distributed across the surface of the ZSM-5 modified with nickel oxide. This uniform distribution reflects the homogeneous dispersion of both the framework elements and the impregnated metal within the material. Particle‑size analysis in Fig. 3(d) and (e) shows that the ZSM‑5 crystals average 946 nm ± 59,2 nm, while those of NiO/ZSM‑5 measure 964 nm ± 61,7 nm, a negligible increase, suggesting that NiO does not appreciably alter crystal dimensions but merely coats the surface. The particle sizes were measured using ImageJ software based on SEM images. Debye–Scherrer calculations from XRD line broadening place the mean NiO crystallite size at ∼6.2 nm, small enough for reasonably uniform dispersion over the zeolite surface. Because this dimension exceeds the intrinsic 2.73 nm micropores (as determined from N₂‑physisorption) yet is far smaller than the 25.25 nm mesopores, NiO crystallites likely do not penetrate the micropore network but instead decorate external surfaces or partially occupy larger mesopores. This scenario is consistent with mild aggregation of NiO on the outer surface and within open pore mouths of the zeolite. Overall, the SEM images visually confirm NiO deposition and corroborate XRD and FTIR findings, the MFI framework remains structurally intact, while nanometre‑sized NiO particles are successfully and evenly introduced as active sites on the hierarchical ZSM‑5 catalyst. NH3‑TPD was employed to probe the acid‑site distribution of pristine ZSM‑5 and NiO/ZSM‑5. The deconvoluted desorption profile in Fig. 4 shows a low‑temperature band at 100–300 °C, assigned to weak acid sites or physisorbed NH3. For unmodified ZSM‑5 this band dominates, indicating that most acid sites are of low strength. After NiO impregnation, the integrated area of this band increases, evidence that the total acid‑site density has grown while its maximum shifts toward higher temperature, signalling an overall enhancement in acid strength. In the medium‑temperature window (300–500 °C) pristine ZSM‑5 exhibits a single peak, whereas NiO/ZSM‑5 displays a split doublet, suggesting the creation of additional medium‑strength sites upon metal loading. Above 500 °C a high‑temperature peak appears in both samples; this is typically attributed to strong Brønsted sites (Si–OH–Al) that retain NH3 most tenaciously. A common feature near 700 °C corresponds to dehydroxylation of the zeolite framework. As shown in Table 2 , NiO/ZSM‑5 contains 0.845 mmol g-1 of total acid sites versus 0.722 mmol g-1 for the parent zeolite, and its fraction of strong sites rises from 37.5 % to 52.9 %. These findings indicate that incorporating NiO boosts both the total amount of acid sites and shifts their distribution toward higher acid strength, which significantly improves NH3 adsorption. Consequently, NiO modification is expected to boost catalytic activity by supplying a larger and intrinsically stronger, population of active acid centres. 3.2 Catalytic tests In the first reaction step, the formation of HMF begins with the isomerization of glucose into fructose, facilitated by Lewis acid catalytic sites. Subsequently, fructose undergoes the elimination of three water molecules via a Brønsted acid pathway, forming the furan ring structure of HMF [11,42]. This process proceeds optimally at elevated temperatures, as sufficient activation energy is required to break C–O bonds and generate the aromatic furan structure. The subsequent step involves oxidizing the hydroxyl and aldehyde functionalities of HMF into carboxyl groups, ultimately yielding FDCA, as illustrated in Fig. 5 , ZSM-5 is known to contain Na+, Al3+, and Ni2+ as Lewis acid sites, while the presence of hydroxyl groups gives rise to Brønsted acid sites [43,44]. These acidic sites are crucial in facilitating the isomerization of glucose to fructose, which proceeds via two main pathways: an intramolecular hydride shift pathway catalysed by the framework of NiO/ZSM-5, and an α-C deprotonation and enediol formation pathway facilitated by extra-framework NiO species. This isomerization involves ring-opening of glucose followed by structural rearrangement into fructose [45], which is then dehydrated into HMF. Upon modification with NiO, ZSM-5 acquires additional Lewis acid sites and redox-active centers, significantly enhancing its bifunctional catalytic performance. NiO species anchored on the external surface and within the mesopores of hierarchical ZSM-5 serve as oxidative centers capable of activating H2O2 and promoting electron transfer processes. These centers enable the oxidation of the hydroxymethyl and aldehyde functional groups of HMF into carboxylic groups, ultimately producing FDCA. Simultaneously, the acidic environment, reinforced by the incorporation of NiO, supports the initial isomerization and dehydration steps [46]. NH3-TPD analysis confirms that NiO/ZSM-5 exhibits higher total acidity and stronger acid sites compared to ZSM-5. Reaction optimisation was carried out with a Box–Behnken design. Peak areas obtained by HPLC were converted to concentrations using previously established calibration curves and then to percentage yields. A twoway ANOVA evaluated the statistical significance of each factor and its interactions. In the glucose to HMF stage, three variables were examined—reaction time (1–3 h), temperature (120–160 °C), and GVL volume (0.4–4 mL). The subsequent HMF to FDCA stage was probed over reaction times of 6–12 h, temperatures of 90–110 °C, and the same GVL range; complete results are listed in Table S1 (30 experimental runs). Under the best glucose dehydration conditions (160 °C, 2 h, 0.4 mL GVL), a 30.9 % HMF yield was achieved. FDCA yields spanned from < 1 % up to 36.05 %, the latter obtained at 90 °C for 12 h with 4 mL neat GVL. The yield value was determined using the calibration curve presented in Fig. S2. The two-way ANOVA results in Fig. 6 indicate that reaction time is the single most influential variable (p = 0.012), followed by the time temperature interaction (p = 0.033). In contrast, temperature and solvent volume, considered individually, exert weaker statistical effects (p > 0.05). These results correspond to our data, showing that the peak FDCA yield occurred at the longest reaction time tested, which was 12 h, which facilitates complete oxidation of HMF through intermediate species such as HMFCA and FFCA before reaching FDCA. Both the Box Behnken model and literature reports G. Chen et al. and Zeng et al. underscore the same point; reaction times shorter than about 10 h convert HMF only as far as HMFCA, whereas 10–12 h are required for full oxidation to FDCA [47,48]. The standardized effect plots in Fig. 6(a) reveal that temperature and its interaction with solvent volume exert the strongest influence on product yield. The highest HMF yield (30.94 %) was achieved at 160 °C for 2.36 h using a total solvent volume of 0.4 mL, corresponding to a GVL:water ratio of 0.4:3.6 mL. Although the amount of GVL is little, its presence is crucial for stabilising the HMF formed. It is suggested that water, the main component of the solvent system, accelerates the glucose-to-fructose isomerisation via ion-mediated pathways promoted by the catalyst, yet it also favours HMF degradation through rehydration and humin formation. The modest addition of GVL therefore balances solvent polarity, suppressing HMF degradation without hindering dehydration. These observations agree with the findings of T. Zhang et al. and Zhao et al., which likewise reported that temperatures above 150 °C are particularly effective in steering glucose dehydration towards HMF [8,49]. The underlying chemistry is supported by the behaviour of GVL, an aprotic solvent with a moderate dielectric constant that stabilises furanic intermediates and suppresses side-product formation that normally occurs under acidic, high-temperature conditions. The 30.05 % HMF yield obtained here aligns with ranges reported in the literature. For instance, Zhao et al. achieved a 47.07 % yield from glucose using an Al-HfOx catalyst in the biphasic SSW–MIBK system, where the organic phase efficiently extracted HMF and mitigated its degradation [8]. Chang et al. reported a 43.2 % yield with a SnO₂/Cr-MOFs/Cr(OH)₃ catalyst in DMSO, benefitting from photothermal synergy that accelerated conversion [50]. Abdul Rani et al. obtained 45.91 % employing TiO₂/NF in an MIBK/H₂O mixture, which likewise curtailed side reactions [51]. Boonyoung et al. reached a top yield of 57 % using NaY combined with formic acid, underscoring the positive role of an added Brønsted acid in boosting conversion [52]. By contrast, systems using Al-SBA-15 in pure water produced markedly lower yields 25 %, because HMF is more prone to degradation in aqueous media [53]. Collectively, these comparisons highlight how catalyst composition, the presence of acidic co-catalysts, solvent environment, and reaction pathway all critically determine the efficiency of glucose-to-HMF conversion. In the oxidation step in Fig. 6(b), the optimum is achieved at a lower temperature (90 °C, 12 h, GVL : H₂O = 4 : 0), delivering a 36.05 % FDCA yield, comparable to the 90–100 °C aqueous or biphasic systems reported by G. Chen et al., Wu et al. and J. Zhang et al. [54–56]. Here, water is essential for dissolving H2O2 and facilitating electron transfer on the transition metal catalyst, while the high GVL content stabilises furan intermediates and curbs side reactions. In a previous study by Herlina et al., HMF was successfully converted into FDCA through a one-pot method, where both reaction stages were carried out in a single reactor without separation [14]. The process yielded FDCA up to 88.9 %, although it faced limitations in terms of selectivity and degradation of intermediates such as HMF. In contrast, this study employs a two-step approach by separating the reaction into two stages; the dehydration of glucose to HMF and the oxidation of HMF to FDCA. This separation offers better control over reaction parameters at each step, potentially minimizing side reactions and improving selectivity. Moreover, the present study demonstrates that the oxidation of HMF to FDCA can proceed effectively at a significantly lower temperature of 90 °C, which enables the use of conventional heating equipment instead of high-pressure systems. Although the reaction time extends to 12 h, three times longer than the method reported by Herlina et al., this strategy improves operational safety and energy efficiency. Compared to Herlina’s method, which achieved a 88.9 % FDCA yield in 4 h at 130 °C using water as the solvent, the current study achieved a 36.05 % yield at 90 °C for 12 h using a mixed solvent of water and GVL. The difference in performance is largely attributed to the type of solvent used; while aqueous systems promote faster conversion, GVL provides a more stable and environmentally friendly reaction environment, albeit with a slower reaction rate. After determining the optimal conditions based on the Box-Behnken design in two separate stages, a subsequent experiment was carried out using a one-pot reaction system, where glucose is directly converted into FDCA within a single reactor without separating the intermediate steps. To support this process, the initial conversion of glucose to HMF was maintained under the previously optimized conditions, namely a high temperature of 160 °C for 2.36 h, which had proven to yield the highest HMF output. The reaction then proceeded at a lower temperature of 90 °C for a total of 12 h to promote the further oxidation of HMF into FDCA. This experiment primarily aimed to assess how different GVL solvent volumes influence the overall conversion efficiency and to compare the catalytic activity of NiO/ZSM-5 with that of unmodified ZSM-5 and a system without catalyst. As shown in Fig. 7 , NiO/ZSM-5 delivered the highest overall FDCA yield (4.22 %), greatly surpassing ZSM-5 (1.21 %) and the blank run (0 %). Even at the extreme solvent ratio of 4 mL GVL : 0 mL H₂O, NiO/ZSM-5 still gave a respectable 0.71 % yield, only slightly lower than the fully biphasic case. Although this yield is significantly lower than the 36.05 % obtained from the two-step process, it remains a meaningful result when considering the overall reaction pathway. In the two-step route, glucose is first converted to HMF with a yield of 30.94 %, followed by oxidation to FDCA, meaning the 4.22 % yield corresponds to 13.6 % conversion of HMF to FDCA. The reduced efficiency in one-pot systems is consistent with literature reports, where side reactions, humin formation, and intermediate instability often suppress FDCA yields [57]. Interestingly, our result is comparable to several noble metal-based catalytic systems. For example, Au/C produced 7 % FDCA at 6.9 bar O₂ and 23 °C for 6 h, while Pd/HT gave 6 % at 1 bar O₂ and 60 °C for 6 h, and Pt/TiO₂ showed only 2 % yield at 1 bar O₂ and 75 °C for 12 h [12,58,59]. These comparisons highlight that despite the lower pressure and simpler setup in system, and without noble metals, NiO/ZSM-5 is still capable of delivering comparable FDCA yields. This underscores the effectiveness of NiO/ZSM-5 as a functional catalyst, combining acid and redox properties essential for glucose dehydration and HMF oxidation under mild, green conditions. TOF values further support this performance enhancement. Compared to ZSM-5, the incorporation of NiO increased the TOF significantly from 11.2 h⁻¹ to 57.1 h⁻¹ (at 0.4 mL GVL: 3.6 mL H₂O), indicating a more efficient utilization of active acid sites. This improvement can be attributed to the increased number of acid sites and their enhanced accessibility [60–62], driven by improved NiO dispersion and the hierarchical mesoporosity of the catalyst. The elevated TOF confirms that the active sites in NiO/ZSM-5 are not only more abundant but also more catalytically effective, facilitating a faster per-site transformation under the applied reaction conditions. Overall, the catalytic tests confirm that NiO/ZSM-5 is far more active than parent ZSM-5. This superiority is consistent with its small NiO crystallite size (∼ 6.2 nm), high specific surface area, and the greater number and strength of acid sites revealed by NH₃TPD. The absence of structural damage after impregnation, verified by XRD, SEM, and FTIR, further supports that the performance gains stem from the introduced NiO rather than from morphological changes in the zeolite. Taken together with the Box–Behnken modelling and two-way ANOVA, these findings show that catalyst modification and the staged one pot strategy markedly improve both the efficiency and selectivity of glucose conversion to FDCA. 4 Conclusions This study shows that modifying ZSM-5 with NiO notably improves the catalytic conversion of glucose to FDCA. The NiO/ZSM-5 catalyst used in a GVL-based solvent system enhanced both catalytic activity and selectivity compared to unmodified ZSM-5. Under optimized conditions (GVL:water ratio of 0.4:3.6, stepwise temperature profile from 160 °C to 90 °C, and reaction times of 2.3 to 12 h), the one-pot system achieved an FDCA yield of 4.22 %, significantly higher than pure ZSM-5 (0.71 %) and the blank system (0 %). The highest individual HMF yield (30.94 %) was reached at 160 °C, 2.36 h, and 0.4 mL GVL: 3.6 mL water, while the highest FDCA yield (36.05 %) was obtained at 90 °C, 12 h, and 4 mL GVL. These optimal conditions, determined via Box–Behnken design and validated by two-way ANOVA, highlight the effectiveness of catalyst modification and reaction design in improving process efficiency and selectivity for sustainable FDCA synthesis. coredata.dc:description: 2,5-Furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) has attracted considerable interest as a sustainable monomer for producing biodegradable polymers such as poly(ethylene furanoate) (PEF), offering a sustainable alternative to petrochemical-derived materials. FDCA may be produced by oxidizing 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), which itself is commonly obtained from the dehydration of fructose or related hexose isomers. This study utilized a nickel oxide-modified ZSM-5 catalyst to facilitate the conversion process. Comprehensive physicochemical analyses were conducted on both ZSM-5 and its NiO-modified counterpart using methods such as X-ray diffraction, infrared spectroscopy, X-ray fluorescence, scanning electron microscopy, nitrogen physisorption, and ammonia temperature-programmed desorption. Catalytic tests followed a two-stage strategy: glucose dehydration to HMF, and subsequent HMF oxidation to FDCA, with reaction parameters optimized by Box–Behnken design. The highest HMF yield (30.94 %) was obtained at 160 °C for 2.36 h using 0.4 mL of gamma-valerolactone (GVL) and 3.6 mL of water. The optimal FDCA yield from HMF (36.05 %) was achieved at 90 °C for 12 h in pure GVL (4 mL). To simplify the process, a one-pot system combining both steps was also explored, resulting in a final FDCA yield of 4.22 % under optimized conditions (GVL:water ratio 0.4:3.6) with NiO/ZSM-5, demonstrating the catalyst's potential in sustainable FDCA production.
